section.title: Review -- Equations that are Quadratic in Form
section.p: Quadratic equations come up often in the problems, but it is not always obvious how. Sometimes it seems like an "algebra trick."
Recall that the quadratic formula says that the solutions to the equation ax^2+bx+c = 0 are x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}
If you have not yet committed this to memory, now is the time.

In our problems, quadratic equations will often be disguised, or "quadratic in form." These equations look like a[f(x)]^2+b[f(x)]+c = 0 for some fucntion f(x). To solve these equations, first use the quadratic formula to solve for possible values of f(x), then solve for the values of x. Some like to use an explicit substitution u=f(x).
